newsitem.title: POLAND: NATO treaty will dispel Russia's fears-Rybkin.
newsitem.headline: NATO treaty will dispel Russia's fears-Rybkin.

text.p: A treaty between Russia and the Atlantic Alliance would allay Moscow's fears over NATO's expansion, the secretary of Russia's Security Council said on Monday.

"Russia's disquiet over NATO's enlargement will be dispelled by the signing of an agreement between Russia and the North Atlantic Alliance," PAP news agency reported Ivan Rybkin, one of Boris Yeltsin's top security advisers, as saying.
Earlier on Monday Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin said in Prague that Moscow would remain opposed to NATO's eastward expansion even after the agreement was concluded.
Rybkin, who is one a two-day working visit the Poland, made the remark to journalists following a meeting wtih Marek Siwiec, chief of Poland's presidential Bureau of National Security.
"European security is not possible without Russia... We want a Europe without divisions. In a new and changing Europe we should be together," he said.
"We want to conduct a dialogue with our great neighbour to the East," Siwiec said. There is no better way to clarify doubts than through direct talks."
Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary are expected to be formally invited to join the alliance at NATO's Madrid summit this July.
Moscow has repeatedly equated the planned enlargement with rolling the NATO war machine up to its borders and insists on a separate treaty giving Moscow a say in the alliance's affairs.
